title: Type design step by step
content:
[http://perso.ensad.fr/%7eensadtypo/](http://web.archive.org/web/20131019074311/http:/perso.ensad.fr/%7eensadtypo/)   
My group of student started to design a typeface together 3 weeks ago. We hope to finish a final font around the end of May. Each friday, I post online couple of comments and bunch of images reporting where they are now. Click on the efojalict image to access to the current stage. Or start with that first one:   
 [http://perso.ensad.fr/%7eensadtypo/travaux/cookerblack.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20131019074311/http:/perso.ensad.fr/%7eensadtypo/travaux/cookerblack.html)   
   
Despite its in French, English comments are welcome via the "commentez" link.   
   
 [http://erik.letterror.com/cgi-python/tm/cooker](http://web.archive.org/web/20131019074311/http:/erik.letterror.com/cgi-python/tm/cooker)   
The subject started his life with the Erik van Blokland TypeCooker (thanks to this list for the announce of it), so, naturally the working name was Cooker Black.
author: jfp

comments.content:
Hello All,   
I am new in this filed. I am designing fonts for Urdu and Punjabi languages, writen in persio-arabic based right to left scripts. I have designed a font.   
But I am facing the problem that it is not very sharp specially on web. I need help in this regards.   
Thanks in advance.   
Abbas Malik

\> not very sharp specially on web.   
   
I guess you mean that it looks bad on the computer screen? This is a tricky issue even with Latin. You either have to learn how to "Hint" your fonts (an extra step in font design where you add "guidelines" for low-resolution rendering to look better), or turn on anti-aliasing for all sizes and live with the resultant blurriness.   
   
hhp

Hi Jean,
